Award.AwardTitle: Toward an Ab-initio Understanding of Ultracold Boson Experiments in One Dimension
Award.AbstractNarration:
The quantum world is a source of uncommon phenomena, such as lasing and superconductivity, that have had tremendous impacts on society. Intrinsically fragile, quantum phenomena are difficult to observe and study, let alone explain. Since the observation of Bose-Einstein condensation in the mid-1990s, ultracold gases (gases at nearly zero absolute temperature) that are trapped and manipulated with electromagnetic fields in vacuum chambers have provided a unique window for the exploration of the quantum world. Experiments with ultracold gases are examining quantum effects when atoms are allowed to move only in one spatial direction. This reduced dimensionality can exaggerate "quantum-ness" and produce novel states of matter. This project will develop theoretical models to describe such states and study their observable properties. The models to be developed are expected to aid in the understanding of materials in which electrons interact strongly and in which their motion along some spacial direction is constrained; for example, in nano-scale wires. The properties of these systems, at odds with those of traditionally studied unconstrained (three-dimensional) quantum systems, might be essential to the understanding of a wide range of nano-devices.

This theoretical research will explore phenomena in quantum gases in equilibrium and far from equilibrium. In equilibrium, one of the questions to be answered is whether the adiabatic loading of three-dimensional Bose-Einstein condensates in two-dimensional optical lattices results in one-dimensional gases that are in thermal equilibrium, or whether generalized Gibbs ensembles are needed to describe them. The researchers will also study phenomena which result when an additional weaker lattice is added along the one-dimensional gas, and the associated quantum phases that are realized experimentally. Far from equilibrium, this project will explore the expansion dynamics of one-dimensional gases in the presence of interactions, with or without an optical lattice along the expansion direction, as well as experiments in which parameters such as the strength of the confining potential or the lattice depth are periodically modulated in time. Another problem to be explored is the result of band-mapping procedures in experiments in which the atoms are far-from-equilibrium and interact strongly. The research proposed will be mostly carried out by two graduate students who will be trained in computational and many-body quantum physics. The PI will design an advanced graduate course on quantum statistical mechanics, and will contribute to the Hazleton Integration Project (http://www.hazletonintegrationproject.com) by giving talks at the Hazleton One Community Center about science in general and physics in particular.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the PI's group's contributions to two experiment/theory collaborations and related purely theoretical developments. The research supported under this award had as central goal gaining a deeper understanding of out-of-equilibrium quantum matter in low dimensions.

The two theory/experiment collaborations explored nonequilibrium quantum dynamics of strongly interacting ultracold one-dimensional gases close to integrable points. This is a novel area of research in which the close collaboration between experiment and theory enabled important developments. A team involving both the experimental group of Prof. Benjamin Lev at Stanford and the PI's group was able to show that equilibration close to strongly interacting integrable points occurs in two steps: a fast prethermal relaxation is followed by a slow near-exponential approach to the thermal result. A second team formed by the experimental group of Prof. David Weiss at Penn State and the PI's group showed that, experimentally studying expansion dynamics, one can measure the distribution of conserved quantities (known as the distribution of rapidities) associated with many-body integrable systems. The latter team was the first to experimentally observe the transformation of the momentum distribution of one-dimensional ultracold bosons between bosonic and fermionic shapes. These two experiment/theory collaborations showed that, contrary to prevalent naive expectations, phenomena associated to integrability are ubiquitous in ultracold gases in one-dimensional geometries.

On the purely theoretical side, the PI's group in collaboration with Prof. Wojciech De Roeck (KULeuven, Belgium) put forward a general yet conceptually simple theoretical framework to understand equilibration in isolated quantum systems in the presence of weakly broken conservation laws. The theoretical framework and numerical experiments carried out by Dr. Krishnanand Mallayya (a graduate student supported by this award) provide a step forward in bridging the gap between the current understanding of quantum microscopic theory and experimental observations. Specifically, the numerical experiments showed that exponential relaxation can occur under pure unitary dynamics with a relaxation rate that can be predicted using Fermi's golden rule. Dr. Mallayya further generalized those ideas to driven quantum systems, and used them to provide insights on the phenomenon of eigenstate thermalization. As part of this theoretical endeavor, Dr. Mallayya developed a powerful computational technique, which goes by the name of numerical linked cluster expansions, that allows one to study quantum dynamics following quenches and under periodic driving in the thermodynamic limit.

Two other important purely theoretical developments were accomplished by Mr. Yicheng Zhang (a graduate student supported by this award) in a collaboration that involved Prof. Lev Vidmar (a former postdoc in the PI's group who is currently at the Jozef Stefan Institute, Slovenia). This collaboration identified bipartite entanglement entropies as global order parameters for the local quantum phase transitions that occur upon the formation or destruction of insulating domains in ultracold gases trapped in one-dimensional lattices. This collaboration also introduced an exact numerical method to calculate equilibrium and far-from-equilibrium one-body correlations of impenetrable SU(N) particles with generalized Neel order. For the latter systems Mr. Zhang showed that, in contrast to most many-body systems in one dimension that exhibit either power-law or exponential decay of one-body correlations in the ground state, impenetrable SU(N) fermions with generalized Neel order exhibit a Gaussian decay. Mr. Zhang also showed that Gaussian correlations emerge during the melting of generalized Neel domain walls. In close relation to the findings of the experiment/theory collaboration with Prof. Weiss' group Mr. Zhang showed that, during the expansion dynamics of impenetrable SU(N) fermions, the momentum distribution transforms into that of free fermions.

Four graduate students were partially supported by this award. They all received training in many-body quantum physics and in advanced computational techniques used to study those systems in an unbiased way. They were also trained in writing efficient computational codes (in C or Fortran 90) and in the use of supercomputers. Two of the students completed their PhDs during the three-year period covered by the award (Dr. Wei Xu in December 2017 and Dr. Krishnanand Mallayya in July 2020).
